content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle, very fun once you understand it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The instructions are easy to understand, and the puzzle can be solved easily by reading carefully. The tests are relevant. Well done!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: doable and nice challenge.

Binary output issue
* According to the contribution guidelines, binary outputs should be avoided for clashes. That's exactly the issue with your clash, as it allows only two possible answers (either 0 or 1).

Please modify the clash to allow for more than two possible answers. One approach could be to introduce an additional input variable for the number of slices of bread required for a sandwich (e.g. for a club sandwich) instead of fixing at 2 slices per sandwich.

Input
* Please change "int" to "integer".

Output
* Please change "int" to "integer".

Stub generator
* Line 2: Please change "S" to "X" for consistency with the Input and Output sections.

Cases
* Test 4: Please reduce N to a value between 30 and 40, so that it aligns more closely with Validator 4.

Thanks.

I updated the problem and changed it so that binary solutions are no longer possible.  Now each loaf has a sandwich type which indicates how many slices of bread is used to make 1 sandwich of that type.  The output is now a 3 line result which gives the remaining bread slices of each type.

The contribution looks better now!

Goal & Output
* Please format "BLT", "Club" and "Sky" as {{constants}}.

Input
* Please change "loafs" to "loaves".

Stub generator
* Line 2: Please update it to the following (feel free to use a different variable name instead of "sandwichType" if you prefer):

loop N read S:int sandwichType:word(4)

* The "write" command accepts a multi-line parameter. Because of this, the second and third "write" statements are being interpreted as part of the first one. Please remove the second and third "write".

Thanks.
